Somali 101 is a grassroots language learning initiative designed to help learners of all ages reconnect with the Somali language in a structured, supportive, and culturally rooted way.
Whether youâ€™re a heritage speaker looking to regain fluency, a complete beginner, or part of the older generation hoping to pass on your knowledge, this project is for you.
The curriculum emphasizes real-world communication, intergenerational learning, and accessible resources. All materials are offered openly to empower communities to teach and learn together.

Muhimmadda Luuqadda Af Soomaaliga â€“ Why Speaking the Somali Language Matters



This disconnection from their mother tongue often leads to a deeper estrangement from their heritage, stories, and identity â€” leaving cultural wisdom unspoken, and generational bonds weakened. Reclaiming the Somali language is not just about communication; it is an act of restoration, belonging, and pride.








A True Story

Hooyadiisa markeey timid dugsigii, wiilkii wuxuu yiri,

Markaan maqlay, waan yaabay, waayo, qofna kama saxin af soomaaligiisa qaldanaa. Waxa laga rabay inuu dheho,
â€œMacalin, ma baxi karaa? Hooyadeey banaankeey joogtaa, ama banaankeey igu sugeeysaa.â€
Maalintaas waxaa igu soo dhacay, â€œamaad adiga laftigaaga ku hadashay af soomaali qaldan sidii saaxiibkaaga Ibraahim?â€
Maalintaas kaddib, waxaan asxaabteeyda iyo waalidkeeyga ka codsaday, haddii aad maqashiin anoo af soomaali qalad ah ku hadlaayo, igu qosol markii hore, kaddib na iga sax.

Growing up, I had a childhood friend named Ibrahim who Iâ€™d see during our weekend school (madrasa/dugsi). He was really bright and had a great sense of humor too.
One day, after he passed his lesson, he was given permission to go home. Long story short, when he finished his lesson and saw his mom parked outside, he asked for permission to leave (in Somali) but did so in an interesting way. Instead of saying â€œmy mom is outsideâ€, he said something along the lines of â€œmy mom is located outsideâ€, using a word more suited to inanimate objects.
I was surprised that no one corrected what sounded like an obvious grammatical mistake. But I felt even worse realizing I too had made similar mistakes and had never been corrected.
In that moment, I began to wonder â€” was I also speaking Somali in a broken way, just like Ibrahim?
From that day forward, I asked my friends and family to gently correct me whenever I spoke Somali incorrectly â€” even laugh a little if needed, then help me improve.
Shortly after, I discovered a grammar book published in Mogadishu in 1973 titled
â€œThe Foundations of Somali Grammar (Aasaaska Naxwaha Af Soomaaliga)â€. Alhamdulillah Iâ€™ve been able to translate this work into English and hope this work benefits any English-speaking Somali who wants to understand the beauty and structure of our mother tongue.

title: Somali 101:Language and Culture Roadmap
text:
This document serves as a comprehensive guide for learners of the Somali language, designed to support both self-study and community-based instruction.
It is a central hub for:

Structured study notes organized by theme

Essential vocabulary relevant to everyday life

Practice exercises for speaking, listening, reading, and writing

Cultural and generational engagement, including Somali proverbs and dialogues

Progress tracking for students over the course of their learning

The course is intended for learners at all levels and is structured as a series of thematic units that build gradually toward fluency. It is especially suited for summer intensives or weekend community classes.







Why Somali Matters



For many Somali youth raised in the West, the inability to speak their mother tongue is a source of quiet grief â€” a feeling of being cut off from elders, stories, and the untranslatable richness of home.
This course is not just about grammar and vocabulary. Itâ€™s about reconnection.
Itâ€™s about helping a generation recover what was almost lost â€” and proudly carry it forward.








Oral Heritage Lives Through Language



Somali has been called a â€œnation of poetsâ€ â€” not because every Somali writes books, but because the oral transmission of wisdom, history, and values has traditionally been carried through language.
Learning Somali is not just learning a language â€” itâ€™s entering a cultural archive.








Language and Identity




When a generation loses its tongue, it also loses its memory.
Preserving Somali is preserving identity â€” not only for individuals, but for families, mosques, and communities seeking continuity.









Somali Proverb




Nin aan dhul marin, dhaayo ma leh.
He who has not traveled has no eyes.

This widely quoted proverb reminds learners that exposure expands understanding â€” just as travel opens the eyes, language opens doors to culture, connection, and insight.




The Somali alphabet uses Latin script with 21 consonants and 5 vowels. It was standardized in 1972 and is written left to right like English. Pronunciation is phonetic, meaning words are typically pronounced as they are spelled.

Somali has 5 vowels: A, E, I, O, U, and each can be:

Short (e.g., run â€“ â€œtrue/truthâ€)
Long (e.g., ruun â€“ â€œhome/settlementâ€)

Long vowels are marked by doubling the letter (aa, ee, ii, oo, uu) and are pronounced longer and more forcefully. They can change the meaning of a word:

Listen and Repeat



The Somali language is best learned by listening. Repeating after a native speaker helps train your ear to subtle sounds like C, DH, and KH.







Ê¾ (Glottal stop) represents a brief pause or a sound from the throat, like a soft catch in the breath â€” similar to Arabic Ø¡ (hamzah).
C is not like the English â€œseeâ€ â€” itâ€™s a voiced pharyngeal sound from the throat (like Arabic Ø¹).
DH is pronounced by curling the tongue back (retroflex). This sound does not exist in English.
KH is like Arabic Ø® â€” a rough â€œkhâ€ from the upper throat.
Q is pronounced deep in the throat â€” not like â€œkâ€, but more forceful (like Arabic Ù‚).
R is lightly rolled, similar to Spanish.
Double vowels (aa, ee, etc.) are longer and often stressed.








Tip for Arabic Speakers



If you know Arabic, Somali letters C, Q, KH, and DH will sound familiar to you. But even native Arabic speakers need to adjust their ear for DH, which is distinct from Arabic sounds.

A good introduction begins with greetings and basic questions. This chapter presents essential words and phrases for you to use when meeting someone new.







Start With What You Know



You donâ€™t need to memorize every word immediately.
Focus on 5â€“7 phrases that you can say confidently â€” like your name, where youâ€™re from, and how youâ€™re doing. Then build from there.
